title: Facebook: Russian disinformation campaign targeted Africa
text:
Facebook has shut down a Russian disinformation campaign in Africa after linking it to a Vladimir Putin ally suspected of meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.

A network of accounts linked to alleged 'troll farm' kingpin Yevgeny Prigozhin were suspended after targeting more than a million people in eight African countries, Facebook announced today.

The Russians had used nearly 200 fake accounts to spread pro-Moscow and anti-Western material to African users.

The discovery will add to mounting fears about Facebook's security amid early signs of Russian attempts to interfere in the 2020 presidential race in the United States.

Discovery: Facebook has shut down a network of accounts linked to alleged Russian 'troll farm' kingpin Yevgeny Prigozhin, pictured left with Vladimir Putin in 2011

The Russian ruse in Africa targeted both Facebook and Instagram users in three separate operations, Facebook said.

The accounts originated in Russia and targeted Madagascar, Central African Republic, Mozambique, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Sudan and Libya.

'Each of these operations created networks of accounts to mislead others about who they were and what they were doing,' said Facebook cybersecurity chief Nathaniel Gleicher said.

'We have shared information about our findings with law enforcement, policymakers and industry partners.'

One operation included 35 accounts and 53 pages that focused on Central African Republic, Mozambique, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast and Cameroon.

The effort attracted some 475,000 followers and spent $77,000 on adverts relating to global and local political news.

These included Russian policies in Africa - where the Kremlin has been seeking to spread its influence - and criticism of French and US policies.

A separate operation targeting Sudan included 20 different accounts and 18 pages, some posing as news organizations.

The third network, focused on Libya, involved 15 accounts and 12 pages posting about local news and geopolitical issues.

The web giant linked the accounts to Yevgeniy Prigozhin, who has been indicted by U.S. special prosecutor Robert Mueller as a principal figure behind an alleged Russian 'troll farm'.

Prigozhin, a catering tycoon, has been nicknamed 'Putin's cook' because of banquets he organised for the Russian leader.

Fears: The discovery will add to mounting concerns about Facebook's security amid early signs of Russian attempts to interfere in the 2020 presidential race

Facebook was widely criticized for allowing Russia's Internet Research Agency to use its platform to spread fake news during the 2016 presidential race.

Russian accounts were blamed for a wave of misinformation during the 2016 campaign, in particular targeting Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.

One Russian troll farm even tried to encourage U.S. 'secessionist movements' in California and Texas, a report said.

Hundreds of fake Facebook accounts, probably run from Russia, spent about $100,000 on ads aimed at stirring up divisive issues, Facebook admitted.

There are already signs of a Russian effort to influence 2020 with accounts originating from Russia taking aim at U.S. political candidates.

Last week Facebook announced it had stopped four new Russian and Iranian attempts to influence the 2020 election by praising Bernie Sanders and attacking Joe Biden.

An Iranian account which 'masqueraded as a news entity' posted on topics including race relations, U.S. and Israeli policy on Iran and the Black Lives Matter movement.

A report said the accounts reused messages from the Internet Research Agency which targeted U.S. audiences in the 2016 presidential election.

'We're constantly working to detect and stop this type of activity because we don't want our services to be used to manipulate people,' Gleicher said.

'In each of these cases, the people behind this activity coordinated with one another and used fake accounts to misrepresent themselves, and that was the basis for our action.'
description: A network of accounts linked to alleged 'troll farm' kingpin Yevgeny Prigozhin (pictured left with Vladmir Putin) were suspended after targeting more than a million people in eight African countries.
